author: jgrinnell0

title: ⌚️ Apple Watch Compass App (Orientation Based Vibration) [Swift]
description:
Trying to see the possibility of an Apple Watch app that notifies (vibration) the user when they are facing North. That's all. No need for other features. No connection to phone/internet.

It would (I believe) primarily use this feature: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/coremotion/cmmagnetometerdata/1616084-magneticfield

And would use the Apple Watch 5 and Later for magnometer (compass) feature.

MVP: If user's wrist is facing 'north', slightly vibrate for 1s.

Acceptance Criteria
MVP or potential for MVP.
A TestFlight ready app that vibrates for 1s when the user faces North each time.
e.g. I walk and turn east, no vibration
I keep waking and turn north, slight 1s vibration.
I turn west, no vibration.
I turn north again, 1s vibration.

title: GPT3 AI Story Video Generator
description:
I would like to create a tool that can create Story Videos based on prompts. It can be a simple command line tool, no need for a website or app.

User inputs story prompt (ex. A story about a girl and a big mountain)
Story is given to GPT-3 API, in a way so that it gives the story text and descriptions of images for the story (to be used by DALLE-2)
Image prompts from GPT-3 output will be fed to DALLE-2 API (or a different image generating AI)
Story is read by Text-To-Speech API (for ex. Azure Cognitive Services)
Audio and Images are combined to create a single video using the https://remotion.dev library.

Basically, the tool should be written in JavaScript, retrieve data from all the required APIs, and use the Remotion library to create a video from these outputs.

I am a coder myself who has used all these API's and libraries before, and I can provide support if you need any help.

title: Workflowy-esque AI Todo list expander
description:
Sometimes a particular task can be daunting, leading to procrastination. An effective solution is to break the task down into a number of simpler, more approachable subtasks. If any of those tasks are still intimidatingly, they can be further subdivided.

Workflowy.com pioneered an infinitely nestable outline interface which is conducive to this type of task subdivision. This bounty is to create a prototype app which improves upon Workflowy by using a LLM to assist in task subdivision.

Acceptance Criteria
 A workflowy-esque webapp, with an intuitive UI allowing the user to build an infinitely nestable outline.
 A function which automatically creates nested subtasks for any given task by using an LLM, such as GPT3
 Your choice of web framework

3) On the leaf node, you will find a link labeled "Download Authenticated PDF".  For example, for the first leaf node, the URL will be https://codes.ohio.gov/assets/laws/revised-code/authenticated/0/1/1.01/6-29-2011/1.01-6-29-2011.pdf

Sometimes you have 100 hours of free time, but only 25 hours of podcasts to listen to. Instead of listening to your favorite podcasts 4 times each, why not listen once at 0.25x speed?

Acceptance Criteria
An easy-to-use webapp that lets the user submit their own podcast, and listen back at 0.25x speed.
Users can submit podcasts in any way that's easy-to-use, such as via Apple podcast link (e.g.https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/season-2-ep-1-the-cursed-production-of-cyber-cowboys/id1561306479?i=1000578054491)
Users should be able to play, pause, rewind 10 seconds, fast-forward 10 seconds, and scrub through the podcast.
It would be super cool if you can adjust the playback speed, but it's not really necessary. Another idea-- it would be really awesome if the playback speed slowly oscillated from 0.25x speed to 0.35x speed, and back and forth. Maybe you would get a really slow Doppler effect?
In designing the web app, feel free to use as many CSS3 transforms and an...

title: C# Script to Parse Specific Piece of Data from a PDF
description:
I have a PDF document with various text and data that I need parsed. Specifically, there is an identification number, an alphanumeric string of five letters and numbers, that I need to have parsed out of the PDF and returned by the script. It's usually in the same place in every PDF form, but that location may change at some point in the future, so a more robust script and regular expression that could still recognize this unique ID number even if it were in a different place in the document would be most ideal. I have used ChatGPT to write a C# script to do this, and it's almost successful, but the regular expressions I have used need to be amended to be more robust and return the correct data every time. The C# script uses the iText library to accomplish the parsing.

Deliverable
One (1) C# script that can successfully return the unique ID number from five different PDF files.

title: Convert former Github CEO's Python code file into Javascript - Use no librares & should run in console of any webpage
description:
Nat Friedman wrote this Python file recently. It drives a web browser using GPT-3, passing in a simplified DOM as part of the prompt.

Here's the file:
https://github.com/nat/natbot/blob/main/natbot.py

I want a simplified DOM - (the browser_content var in the file) - obtained with just JS and no external library (e.g. no playwright lib), and constructed from JS I can run in my console.

Acceptance Criteria

I should be able to paste your JS code into any webpage and have it return a simplified DOM that's identical/near-identical to the browser_content in this python code.

I should be able to run 'click(id)', type('id') etc. just like this python file https://github.com/nat/natbot/blob/f99518d3deee33cb117166049e1c99314080f7e5/natbot.py#L191

* I am a DJ. I can not mix video without affecting audio on scratch mode. *

Solution

Using 2 video streams and muting one track, mix the other while in sync, one video is muted, and the audio stays unaffected.

I have got this to work without code. I can set this up manually. It should only take a pro about an hour, but if someone wants to learn and take longer, still apply.

I have a patent description for this — also an example video.

There is an SDK kit on the website, and they recommend C++
(Maybe with Ghostwriter, you can convert the code if C++ is not your thing)

[Virtual DJ site] (https://www.virtualdj.com/wiki/Developers)

*You do not need a controller; this costs nothing; VDJ is free and open-sourced.

I am also happy to learn; teach me how you did it.

In return, I could teach you some DJing.

title: Playground for local models
description:
The goal is to create a web UI like the OpenAI playground that can be used to test your own models (e.g. a T5 finetune). This would require having all the nice UI features of the OpenAI playground, including:

model selection
generation parameter selection (temp, max length, etc).
stop sequence, start text, restart text
the ability to show probabilities
green text that behaves like the OpenAI green text
undo / regenerate buttons
saving/loading presets

Acceptance Criteria

Your solution should be written in Python (since the people using this are mostly Pythonistas). I should be able to easily run this and launch a web UI where I can select a model from HuggingFace, and have a UI experience that's hard to distinguish from the OpenAI playground.

At minimum you should be able to load models locally. For extra credit, consider adding support for remotely inferencing models on huggingface, modal, replicate, cohere, etc.

You can also opt to write an iOS application instead of Android. However, I think iOS will be much harder since iOS disallows background video, you'll have to work around it by either 1) publishing on a sideloading app store, so not officially downloadable or 2) using a zoom-like technique where the video is in a small screen in the corner on top of the current application. When I untar the compressed file, I want to get exactly the first file but I don't, and the size is even incorrect.

Acceptance Criteria
You should be able to decompress the linked .tar.gz file into the linked decompressed file, with the same size and contents, in localforage.

Technical Details
There is more elaboration on the problem here: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/75105921/tar-gz-decompression-with-ts-results-in-different-files-in-the-browser?noredirect=1#comment132567618_75105921

The real size is 1.428 kB. Using tar-stream gives a file that is 20.48 kB, pako gives 9.847 kB or 10.240 kB. The size doesn't even match up.

Link to Project
You can see some code snippets here: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/75105921/tar-gz-...

title: Video Combiner
description:
I have a set of between 2-10 videos. These videos are of a lecture classroom from different angles. One of the videos has audio. I want a script I can run on a folder of .mp4 files. You should detect the filenames automatically, extract the audio from the one that has audio (we don't know in advance which one it is), and then generate one combined video. This combined video should smartly use heuristics to choose which video to show at that second. One good starting heuristic is that the video with the most movement in those 20 frames should be shown. We don't want it to switch every 20 frames, so if there's a lot of switching, we should also detect that and not switch as often.

I am running MacOS, so it should work on a Mac.

Acceptance Criteria
I will strongly prefer people who provide a clear outline of how they would build it (i.e. some of the tools or algorithms they'd use). I will also prefer people who have Githubs or resumes with past work.

title: Timed Comments for Youtube
description:
Project Description
Timed comments for YouTube (like the existing beta which doesn't seem likely to rollout soon). Basically, I want a way to embed YouTube videos and to show an auto-scrolling comments board beneath it, on my Jekyll site. There should be a way to
1) Use the Youtube API to get the current second that the user is at in the video.
2) Scrape all of the comments from that video and show them beneath the video. Prioritize timestamped comments, and show the ones closest to the current timestamp first.
3) It should show each YouTube comment thread in a default-collapsed style, where only the highest rated comment is shown, and there are ways for me to add a comment either to any thread or to the top level. The UI can look like YouTube comments or SoundCloud comments.
4) It should be possible for me to comment on any thread or post my own comment, and that comment should be posted to Youtube along with the current timestamp that I'm at.

I have been using chatGPT to do this. I feed it a block of text between two subject headings and ask it to summarize each block. Acceptance Criteria

I am looking for an app that will automate this process. Ideally, I would like to feed in a url from an article on my site and have the app spit out a 4-6 bullet point summary of the article. Behind the scenes, the app is cutting up the article into digesti...

title: DefiLlama adapter adapter
description:
Defillama has a lot of adapters in https://github.com/DefiLlama/DefiLlama-Adapters, for their website and api (defillama.com). I need a standalone wrapper, or modified defilamma sdk, that can run each adapter, get the data out, and send it as a protobuf message to kafka.
Protobuf definition should be defined including these keys because all the adapters return data that fall under these labels.

['tvl', 'staking', 'pool2', 'borrowed', 'treasury', 'offers', 'vesting'] along with timestamp.

Acceptance Criteria
A .proto definition
Either a standalone wrapper or a modified defillama sdk that can send protobuf messages to a kafka broker endpoint. The adapters that connect directly to RPC must run. The adapters that depend on The Graph are optional but may work without any modification.
Readme on how to run this
small tests (to ensure cli args and options are working correctly)

The deadline and bounty can be adjusted. Open to offers.

Controls:
  A left D right W center thrust SPACE start,

author: Altify-Developm

title: Extend ebean to prepend caller class and line number in SQL comment
description:
Ebean is an ORM for JVM languages. Using performance monitoring tools, it is currently difficult to match a slow query generated by Ebean to the code that generated it.

We can solve this by optionally (enabled using configuration properties in application.yaml) prepending the caller class and line number in a comment on each generated query.

For example, instead of select t0.uuid, t0.createdat... we would generate /* MyClass:123 */ select t0.uuid, t0.createdat...

Delivery is a PR against the ebean project (https://github.com/ebean-orm). If not accepted by ebean's maintainers, we'll fork it.

Acceptance Criteria
Correctly prepends caller class name and line number to every query when enabled by configuration
Has no effect if not enabled by configuration
Works in both Kotlin and Java projects
Unit tests cover the core comment behavior and have 100% coverage of newly added lines

Link to Project
https://github.com/ebean-orm

title: Generate list of auto-complete import options from parsing TypeScript definitions/AST
description:

I have a work-in-progress solution which does not yet work for all cases. I would like help to complete it so I can focus on other parts of my app.

I want to enumerate the possible auto-complete import options for a package given the package's TypeScript definitions (e.g. d.ts files from DefinitelyTyped).

Example: Lodash package
See https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.15

For example:
import { /* HERE */ } from "lodash";

Should list those shown in the documentation: https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.15#orderBy
chunk
compact
...
orderBy

import { chunk, compact, orderBy } from "lodash"; // VALID

However, it should NOT list those which are from instances:
toJSON, valueOf, value, etc are shown in the docs ( https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.15#prototype-value ), however, they are attached to an instance not directly from the import.

import { toJSON, valueOf, value } from "lodash" // INVALID/ERROR: these do not exist...

title: Reverse Engineer an app and expose private APIs
description:
Access to the private APIs of specific applications can streamline numerous tasks for users, with their consent.
The bounty entails reverse engineering a bank application and successfully simulating a login into an account. It is not necessary to have an active account on the app. Satisfactory completion involves intercepting the request, exposing the endpoint and payload, and then replicating it using Postman, even if the response is for invalid credentials.

App: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.mashreq.NeoApp&hl=en&gl=US

Acceptance Criteria
The desired outcome is a repackaged APK that can be utilized with tools such as Burp, Charles, or other software to intercept requests. This could also be applicable to iOS. The acceptance criteria include a clear set of instructions for setting up the app, simulating actions, and observing the API calls and payloads.

Ideal Process after your Pull request is accepted:
1) I make my changes/update a word or 2 in the LogSeq desktop app
2) I press Cmd + Shift + S to save it/publish it to my site. (Or press publish on a button in the top right)
3) It pushes all changes through to my custom domain

Ideal process to setup public site:
1) Press publish in top right of LogSeq desktop App
2) Enter custom domain
3) Get CNAME/DNS records
4) Change CNAME on Namecheap/Godaddy/etc (...wait for verification)
5) Publish site to new domain

Ideally, the site should be hosted on a Vercel free plan (Would prefer NOT to create a Vercel account, but understand if that need to be a step for mvp.) for speed and SEO.

title: Talking Harry Potter-style Painting
description:
Talk to a 'painting' and have it talk back, like Harry Potter paintings.

Detect voice coming from the always-on speaker, and when a specific name is uttered, start paying more attention (i.e. it should detect me saying, "Plato, what would you say about the rapid industrialization of society?"). There are many open source programs for similar wake word detection. Then, the desktop should run speech-to-text on that voice. Then, it will pass that text into chatgpt to generate the response to that conversation. While ChatGPT is generating a response, it will fill that lag gap with some templated responses (like, "Great question! I have spent decades pondering this very idea" or whatever). Then, using tokkingheads/another deepfakes-type model to modify both the voice and the face, to have their face pretend like they're saying the response. Once the ChatGPT text starts coming, stream it sentence by sentence to the painting so the animation looks smooth.

I will run this...

title: Spread the word about FindAI.io
description:

FindAI.io is the go-to destination for discovering the best AI tools.

Create a video on TikTok, Instagram, YouTube, or Snapchat to demonstrate the features of FindAI.io. Receive a reward when the video reaches at least 100K views. As we are based in Europe, we prioritize viewers from Europe and North America for this reward.

Acceptance Criteria
To be eligible for the bounty, you must:

Share analytics of the video and the actual video link.
Clearly mention "findai.io" in the video.
Include the website address (findai.io or https://findai.io) in the description of the video
Share your social accounts via email ([email protected]) to get your application accepted.

title: Hoon CodeMirror grammar and language mode

Hoon is a programming language used in the Urbit operating system. You can find the grammar specification for Hoon in the official Hoon documentation. You can use the Hoon mode for Emacs and the Vim package for reference: hoon-mode.el and hoon.vim.

Replit uses CodeMirror as the editor and we want to add first-class support for Hoon, including syntax highlighting. We have a language mode template available on Replit (please read the README for guidance).

We'll publish it as an open source package and credit you.

Acceptance Criteria

Syntax highlighting should match the modes for Hoon in the Emacs and Vim packages
Folding ranges should be added to improve code folding
Should use lezer instead of custom tokenization

description:

Provide recommendations based on user inputs.
Allow for continuous conversations with users to optimize the answers in the recommender as well as personalize it.

Once all the recommendations are shortlisted, given an option to see gifts matching available products in our inventory. Model will need to be trained on available products which can be pulled via an API.

Problem Description

User enters a text message (there is an option to pick a random message from the Emotion dataset: https://huggingface.co/datasets/emotion)

title: Sveltekit with Auth0 properly configured

There is no supported library for auth0 and sveltekit. Implementations we've tried have not allowed for a working load function. Our application will call an external api for data and needs to be able to pass along the bearer token to the api.

Acceptance Criteria
A new sveltekit app, with the ability to log in to auth0, and be able to pass a valid bearer token to an api endpoint in a load function of a page.

Technical Details
Our examples have tried using an SPA version of auth0 and subscribing to stores for the ability to call the remote servers, but the subscribing to a store seems to cause issues with the load function ever refreshing. We think the right approach is something more in the next.js direct. We have an example library here, but we haven't gotten this to work either. https://github.com/rmunn/sveltekit-auth0-unofficial
